query.description: (Required) A geoJSON geometry of a requested object, e.g. polygon, area of interest, etc.
An EPSG code of request's spatial parameters (like `geometry`), e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator).

Size (in meters) of the buffer around the requested geometry.

Negative values cause bounding box of the buffered geometry to be taken (in such a case the geometry is buffered with the absolute value of the parameter value).

Minimum coverage provided by an acquisition to be included in the response.
  
0 means no coverage and 1 means full coverage only.
  
Providing a value will cause coverage statistics to be included in the response.

Default value varies between indicators. You can check it using the `/indciator` endpoint.

Beginning of the queried time period.

The default value is `date - period`.

End of the queried time period.

The default value is `date + period`.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

A value of `now` indicates the current date.

A default value is the current date.
An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

Raster data zoom level.
  
The raster piramids level to be used to fetch the data from - see [here](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames#Resolution_and_Scale) for details.
  
Range of available values vary between indicators. You can check it using the `/indicator` endpoint.

The default value is the maximum value available for a given indicator.

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

request.description:
Returns a list of rasters matching a given search criteria (geometry, time period, coverage) with some basic statistics about raster values.

Results are sorted according to the time difference between their acquisition dates and the `date` parameter. 

Queried period is defined either using combination of `date` and `period parameters of using `dateFrom` and `dateTo` parameters (see below).

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

query.description: (Required) A geoJSON geometry of a requested object, e.g. polygon, area of interest, etc.
An EPSG code of request's spatial parameters (like `geometry`), e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator).

Size (in meters) of the buffer around the requested geometry.

Negative values cause bounding box of the buffered geometry to be taken (in such a case the geometry is buffered with the absolute value of the parameter value).

An EPSG code of returned spatial objects projection, e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator)

If not provided `srcSrid` parameter value is used and if `srcSrid` parameter isn't provided as well, a default value of `4326` is assumed.

Minimum coverage provided by an acquisition to be included in the response.
  
0 means no coverage and 1 means full coverage only.
  
Providing a value will cause coverage statistics to be included in the response.

Default value varies between indicators. You can check it using the `/indciator` endpoint.

Beginning of the queried time period.

The default value is `date - period`.

End of the queried time period.

The default value is `date + period`.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

Default value is indicator-specific. You can check it using the `/indicator` endpoint.

Returned raster data format.
  
It doesn't determine the response format (this is determined by the `format` parameter) and is affected by the `encode` parameter.
Determines the way raster image data are encoded so they can be send as a part of a JSON response.

Determines the way raster values are scaled.
  
* raw - use values as they are stored in the database (e.g. 0-80 for LAI)
* real - rescale values to indicator's phisical values range (e.g. 0-8 fro LAI)
* stdfloat - standardize to mean 0 and standard deviation 1 within the scene
* stdbyte - standardize to mean 127 and standard deviation 25 within the scene
* stretch - transform in a way the minimum value within the scene equals 0 and maximum equals 254
* grayscale - transform in a way minimum phisical value of the indicator corresponds to 0 and maximum to 254

Determines if a color map should be used.
  
* `0` indicates no color map should be used. This value is automatically enforced when `rasterFormat` is other than `image/png`, `image/jpeg` or `image/tiff`.
* `1` indicates a default color map for a given `indicatorId` should be used. Takes effect only when `scale` equals to `raw`.
* `mapName` indicates name of the color map to be used. There are a few general-use color maps available: `viridis1`, `viridis2`, `plasma1`, `plasma2` (see [here](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/viridis/vignettes/intro-to-viridis.html#the-color-scales)), `bw` (black-white), `wb` (white-black) and `ndvi`. They are meant to work with values in `0-254` scale. If the indicator you are using is on a different scale, use `scale=grayscale` parameter to map it to `0-254`. The difference between `viridis1`/`viridis2` and `plasma1`/`plasma2` is the scale direction.
* `postgisColorMapDef` explicitely provided color map. This allows you to apply any color map of your choice. It just has to follow the the format used by the Postgis [ST_ColorMap()](https://postgis.net/docs/RT_ST_ColorMap.html) function. Remember the map is applied to the already values transformed according to the `scale` request parameter.

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.
(Required) Requested date. A special value of `now` indicates the current date.

request.description:
Returns a raster image for a given indicator.

The image acquired at date closest to the `dateId` parameter within the queried period (see `dateFrom`, `dateTo` and `period` parameters) which passes the `minCover` condition is returned.
If there is no such image, 404 is returned.

Returned data include encoded image, its envelope, actual aquisition, the coverage ratio and some basic pixel value statistics.

Data can be scalled and colored according to the `scale` and `colorMap` parameter values.

When negative number is provided, the final `geometry` will be a bounding box of original `geometry` with a positive buffer value applied.

The raster piramids level to be used to fetch the data from - see [here](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames#Resolution_and_Scale) for details.
  
Range of available values vary between indicators. You can check it using the `/indicator` endpoint.

The default value is the maximum value available for a given indicator.

Determines the way values are scaled.

* raw - use values as they are stored in the database (e.g. 0-80 for LAI)
* real - rescale values to indicator's phisical values range (e.g. 0-8 fro LAI)
* stdfloat - standardize to mean 0 and standard deviation 1 within the scene
* stdbyte - standardize to mean 127 and standard deviation 25 within the scene
*  stretch - transform in a way theminimum value within the scene equals 0 and maximum equals 254
* grayscale - transform in a way minimum phisical value of the indicator corresponds to 0 and maximum to 254

Beginning of the queried time period.

The default value is `date - period`.

End of the queried time period.

The default value is `date + period`.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

A value of `now` indicates the current date.

A default value is the current date.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

Default value is indicator-specific. You can check it using the `/indicator` endpoint.

Minimum coverage provided by an acquisition to be included in the response.
  
0 means no coverage and 1 means full coverage only.
  
Providing a value will cause coverage statistics to be included in the response.

Default value varies between indicators. You can check it using the `/indciator` endpoint.

An EPSG code of returned spatial objects projection, e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator)

If not provided `srcSrid` parameter value is used and if `srcSrid` parameter isn't provided as well, a default value of `4326` is assumed.
Requested return format.

The position within a pixel being used as a pixel's vector representation.

* `corner` indicates upper-left corner
* `center` indicates center
* `polygon` indicates a polygon covering whole pixel area

query.description: Returned legend height in pixels. If it's not provided, the legend width will be determined automatically based on the number of labels.
Legend background color in any format understood by the Imagick library (`white`,  `rgb(100, 50, 20)`, `rgba(100, 50, 20, 0.8)`, etc.).
Label font size in points (assuming that the legend has 72 dpi resolution).
Label font color in any format understood by the Imagick library (`white`,  `rgb(100, 50, 20)`, `rgba(100, 50, 20, 0.8)`, etc.).
Width of the color bars in the returned legend. The total legend width depends on the labels length and can't be explicitely requested.

Sets the color map to be used by the legend.

The color map can be one of predefined map names (see also the `colormap` parameter of the `/indicator/{indicatorId}/rasterData` endpoint) or an explicit color map in the Postgis ST_ColorMap() function format.

Normally the colormap is determined by indicator settings (see the `/indicator` endpoint) but this parameter allows to manually enforce it.

Legend type. Discrete legends are displayed as rectangles while continuous ones as a gradient.

Normally the legend type is determined by indicator settings (see the /indicator endpoint) but this parameter allows to manually enforce it.

Sets the set of labels to be displayed on the legend.

Every label is described in a single line starting with the corresponding `colormap` value followed by a space and a label (e.g. `10 foo` means "display label "foo" next to the colormap value 10").

Normally labels are determined by indicator settings (see the `/indicator` endpoint) but this parameter allows to manually enforce them.
For the `class` indicator only - identifier of the classification.

There are a few general-use color maps available: `viridis1`, `viridis2`, `plasma1`, `plasma2` (see [here](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/viridis/vignettes/intro-to-viridis.html#the-color-scales)), `bw` (black-white), `wb` (white-black) and `ndvi`. * `postgisColorMapDef` explicitely provided color map. This allows you to apply any color map of your choice. It just has to follow the the format used by the Postgis [ST_ColorMap()](https://postgis.net/docs/RT_ST_ColorMap.html) function. Remember the map is applied to the already values transformed according to the `scale` request parameter.

query.description: (Required) A geoJSON geometry of a requested object, e.g. polygon, area of interest, etc.
An EPSG code of request's spatial parameters (like `geometry`), e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator).

An EPSG code of returned spatial objects projection, e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator)

If not provided `srcSrid` parameter value is used and if `srcSrid` parameter isn't provided as well, a default value of `4326` is assumed.

Defines the queried area as a registered polygon with a given id.
  
If this parameter is used:
  
* `ownerId` must be provided as well.
* authorization is performed against the polygon's owner account (instead of API users accounts)
Beginning of the time period used for the segmentation (see the endpoint description for details). If not provided, `today - 14 days` is assumed.
End of the time period used for the segmentation (see the endpoint description for details). If not provided, today is assumed.
Minimal required coverage for the requested region (from 0 - none to 1 - full). Dates with lower coverage are skipped in the response.

Should B04 (visible red), B08 (NIR) and B11 (SWIR) bands be included in the segmentation (see the endpoint description for details).

Always `0` if `dateFrom` isn't equal `dateTo` or `scale` isn't equal `raw`.

Determines the way raster values are scaled.
  
* raw - use values as they are stored in the database (e.g. 0-80 for LAI)
* real - rescale values to indicator's phisical values range (e.g. 0-8 fro LAI)
* stdfloat - standardize to mean 0 and standard deviation 1 within the scene
* stdbyte - standardize to mean 127 and standard deviation 25 within the scene
* stretch - transform in a way the minimum value within the scene equals 0 and maximum equals 254
* grayscale - transform in a way minimum phisical value of the indicator corresponds to 0 and maximum to 254
Minimum segment size in pixels (one pixel is around 100 squere meters)
Spatial radius parameter of the mean shift segmentation algorithm.
Range radius parameter of the mean shift segmentation algorithm.
Radius of the simplification window function (value of `0` turns off the simplification step.
Radius of the blur window (value of `0` turns off the blur step)

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

request.description:
Performs a segmentation of a given area using a given indicator.

The segmenation is performed in following steps:

* A set of images is gathered based on the `indicatorId`, `dateFrom`, `dateTo`, `rgb` and `minCover` parameter values. All images being used have to provide at least `minCover` area of the requested `geometry`. If there is no such image, an error is returned.
  * If `dateFrom` differs from `dateTo` all acquisitions of the `indicatorId` indicator within a given time period.
  * If `dateFrom` equals `dateTo` and `rgb` equals `1`, `indicatorId` indicator, B04 (visible red), B08 (NIR) and B11 (SWIR) bands from from a given date are used.
  * If `dateFrom` equals `dateTo` and `rgb` equals `0`, `indicatorId` from a given date is used.
* If `scale` isn't `raw` a corresponding transformation (see `scale` parameter description below) is applied to all images selected in the previous point. The transformation is applied separately for every image.
* If `blur . 0`, a mean filter with a window size of `2 * blur + 1` is applied to all selected images.
* A mean shift segmentation is performed using `spatialR` and `rangeR` parameters.
* If `simplifyR > 0`, a transformation marking a given pixel as belonging to the segment with the highest pixel count in the window of size `2 * simplifyR + 1` is applied.
* If `minSize > 0`, every segment with an area lower than `minSize` pixels is merged with an adjacent segment having closest mean value of the `indicatorId` indicator. This procedure is repeated until there is no segment with size lower than `minSize`.
* `polygonId` may be provided instead of the `geometry` parameter. In such a case given polygon's geometry will be used as the segmentation area.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

query.description:
Defines the queried area as a registered polygon with a given id.
  
If this parameter is used:
  
* `ownerId` must be provided as well.
* authorization is performed against the polygon's owner account (instead of API users accounts)

Id of the `polygonId` owner.
  
To be provided only when `polygonId` parameter is used.

Defines the queried area as a XYZ tile in the `x_y_z` format.
  
See [here](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames) for details.
  
Can be combined with `geometry` or `polygonId`. In such a case the returned raster extent will be determined by this parameter but all pixels outside of `geometry`/`polygonId` will be set to no data.

Defines the queried area as a geoJSON geometry.
  
Geometry's projection should be provided with the `srcSrid` parameter.

Defines the queried area as a bounding box in the `x1,y1,x2,y2` format.
  
Coordinates projection should be provided with the `srcSrid` parameter.
An EPSG code of request's spatial parameters (like `geometry`), e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator).

Raster data zoom level.
  
The raster piramids level to be used to fetch the data from - see [here](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames#Resolution_and_Scale) for details.
  
Range of available values vary between indicators. You can check it using the `/indicator` endpoint.

The default value is the maximum value available for a given indicator.

A buffer size (in meters) to be applied to the `geometry`.
  
Usefeul when `geometry` is a point or to assure returned raster data contains also pixels which centroids don't intersect th `geometry`.

When negative number is provided, the final `geometry` will be a bounding box of original `geometry` with a positive buffer value applied.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

A value of `now` indicates the current date.

A default value is the current date.
An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

Beginning of the queried time period.

The default value is `date - period`.

End of the queried time period.

The default value is `date + period`.

If not present or with the `0` value, data is gathered from actual acquistions.

If `daily=1`, interpolated daily data is used instead. This assures data exists for each day in the requested time period. Daily data are generated on the fly and cached. It means if you request data outside of cache, generating them will take (a lot of) time.

This parameter is still in experimental phase and may not work correctly.

Minimum coverage provided by an acquisition to be included in the response.
  
0 means no coverage and 1 means full coverage only.
  
Providing a value will cause coverage statistics to be included in the response.

Default value varies between indicators. You can check it using the `/indciator` endpoint.

Determines the way raster values are scaled.
  
* raw - use values as they are stored in the database (e.g. 0-80 for LAI)
* real - rescale values to indicator's phisical values range (e.g. 0-8 fro LAI)
* stdfloat - standardize to mean 0 and standard deviation 1 within the scene
* stdbyte - standardize to mean 127 and standard deviation 25 within the scene
* stretch - transform in a way the minimum value within the scene equals 0 and maximum equals 254
* grayscale - transform in a way minimum phisical value of the indicator corresponds to 0 and maximum to 254

Response format.
  
The actual content of the `application/*` responses depends on `encode` parameter value.

`image/tiff` response format returns acquisitions stacked as bands.

As `image/jpeg`, `image/png` and geoJSON response formats are unable to return more that one acquisition, only the most recent one is returned.

Returned raster data format.
  
It doesn't determine the response format (this is determined by the `format` parameter) and is affected by the `encode` parameter.

Determines if a color map should be used.
  
* `0` indicates no color map should be used. This value is automatically enforced when `rasterFormat` is other than `image/png`, `image/jpeg` or `image/tiff`.
* `1` indicates a default color map for a given `indicatorId` should be used. Takes effect only when `scale` equals to `raw`.
* `mapName` indicates name of the color map to be used. There are a few general-use color maps available: `viridis1`, `viridis2`, `plasma1`, `plasma2` (see [here](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/viridis/vignettes/intro-to-viridis.html#the-color-scales)), `bw` (black-white), `wb` (white-black) and `ndvi`. They are meant to work with values in `0-254` scale. If the indicator you are using is on a different scale, use `scale=grayscale` parameter to map it to `0-254`. The difference between `viridis1`/`viridis2` and `plasma1`/`plasma2` is the scale direction.
* `postgisColorMapDef` explicitely provided color map. This allows you to apply any color map of your choice. It just has to follow the the format used by the Postgis [ST_ColorMap()](https://postgis.net/docs/RT_ST_ColorMap.html) function. Remember the map is applied to the already values transformed according to the `scale` request parameter.

Determines the way raster data values are represented.

* `raw` means raster data will be provided as they are. This value is set automatically for `image/*` reponse formats (when `format` equals to `image/png`, `image/jpeg` or `image/tiff`) and is invalid for other response formats.
* `base64` and `hex` means raster data will be base64 or hex encoded. This settings are valid only when `format` equals to `application/json` and `rasterFormat` is one of `image/png`, `image/jpeg` or `image/tiff`.
* `values` causes pixes values to be converted into a vector representation. If the `format` indicates geoJSON response, every pixel will be turned into a geoJSON feature and for `application/json` response format pixels will be represented by a collection of objects providing pixel position and value. The way pixel position is represented is determined by the `position` parameter.
* `stats` causes raster data to be skipped and only summary statistics (valid pixel count, requested area coverage, min, max, mean value, standard deviation) to be returned.

The position within a pixel being used as a pixel's vector representation.

* `corner` indicates upper-left corner
* `center` indicates center
* `polygon` indicates a polygon covering whole pixel area
Maximum number of acqusitions returned (0 means no limit).

Determines if the output should be aggregated to a single raster over acqisition dates and if so, which aggregate function should be used.

The aggregation is performed **after** applying the `scale` parameter and **before** `colorMap`, `limit`, `format`, `rasterFormat`, `encode`, `position` and `srid` ones. 

Aggregation forces raster output pixel format to 32-bit float.

An EPSG code of returned spatial objects projection, e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator)

If not provided `srcSrid` parameter value is used and if `srcSrid` parameter isn't provided as well, a default value of `4326` is assumed.
**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Daily data interpolation method (_l_ - linear, _w_ - whitakker smoother)
**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Whittaker smoother _lambda_ parameter (the bigger the value, the more smoothed output)

**(valid only for the _mzm_ and _irp_ indicators)** 

* For _mzm_: Minimum number of valid acquisitions to provide a smoothed data series for a pixel when the whittaker smoother is used.
* For _irp_: Minumum number of valid acquisitions to consider output of a pixel valid.

Default value can be obtained from the /indicator endpoint
**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Number of whittaker smoother loops.
**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Minimal NDVI value to start the _mzm_ indicator computation (evalutated on a pixel level).
**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Minimal NDVI value ending the _mzm_ indicator computation (evalutated on a pixel level).

**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Minimum length (in days) of a period for which the _mzm_ indicator is computed (evalutated on a pixel level). 

In other words the `endValue` is checked only after `minPeriodLength` days from NDVI reaching the `startValue` (on a pixel level).

**(valid only for the _mzm_ and _irp_ indicators)** Slope coefficient used in the indicator formula.

Default value can be obtained from the /indicator endpoint

**(valid only for the _mzm_ and _irp_ indicators)** Constant coefficient used in the indicator formula.

Default value can be obtained from the /indicator endpoint
**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Coefficient used in the _mzm_ indicator standarization formula.

**(valid only for the _mzm_ indicator)** Buffer (in meters) used to compute resulting raster statistics. It's used to avoid noise which can be introduced by the pixels on the border of the processed geometry.
**(valid only for the _mzm_ and _irp_ indicators)** Coma separated list of data acquisition dates (in _YYYY-MM-DD_ format) to be used for the indicator computation.

**(valid only for the _mzm_ and _irp_ indicators)** Source of the ET0 (base evapotranspiration) data. Use with caution.

Be aware different sources have different spatial and temporal coverages and there's no API allowing to check it.

* raster - forecasts from Australian Meteo Office
* coala - interpolation based on public historical data from meteo stations published by the Australian Meteo Office
* metgis - forecasts from the metgis service
* openweather - forecasts from the openweather service
**(valid only for the _et_ indicator)** Leaf resistance parameter value used in the _et_ indicator formula.
**(valid only for the _et_ indicator)** Crop height (in meters) parameter value used in the _et_ indicator formula.
**(valid only for the _et_ indicator)** Atmospheric pressure (in kPa) parameter value used in the _et_ indicator formula.
**(valid only for the _cwr_ indicator)** Value of the A coefficient in the CWR computation formula)

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

request.description:
A pocket knife for raster data access. This endpoint allows to fetch almost any raster data in almost any format. It's being used under the hood by most other API endpoints.

Endpoint parameters form few groups:

* Queried area definition.
  * It can be done in four ways - by providing `geometry`, `bbox`, `polygonId` or `xyzId`.
  * `geometry`, `bbox` and `polygonId` are affected by `buffer`
  * `geometry` and `bbox` require `srcSrid` to be provided (until the default `srcSrid` value of `4326` is correct)
  * `xyzId` can be used with `geometry` or `polygonId` (see the `xyzId` description)
* Queried time period definition: `dateFrom`, `dateTo`, `date` and `period`.
* Query filter: `minCover`.
* Output format: `format`, `rasterFormat`, `encode`, `position`, `srid`.
* Raster values transformation: `scale` and `colorMap`.
* Other: `limit`.

Most parameters have sane defaults, so to at the beginning focus on `indicatorId`, `dateFrom`, `dateTo`, `format` and optionally `encode` and add others only when needed.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

variable.description:
(Required) Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

request.description:
Returns a list of available indicators, their properties and default settings.

Provided indicator data include:

* `indicatorId`
* `scale` coefficient used to transform indicator stored (so-called raw) value to its phisical value (`phisicalValue = rawValue * scale`)
* `defaultDate` default value of the `date` request parameter
* `defaultPeriod` default value of the `period` request parameter
* `defaultMinCover` default value of the `minCover` request parameter
* `defaultColorMap` default value of the `colorMap` request parameter
* `smoothingLambda` whittaker smoother lambda parameter used for generation of interpolated daily data series (see the `daily` parameter of the `/indicator/{indicatorId}/rasterData` endpoint)
* `minZoomLevel` minimum value of the `z` request parameter
* `maxZoomLevel` maximum value of the `z` request parameter
* `grayscaleMinValue` lower bound of indicator's value range. It is applied to indicator's stored (so-called raw) values which may differ from phisical ones (see `scale` above). This parameter (as well as `grayscaleMaxValue`) may or may not cover the whole theoretical indicator's value range. It's meant to provide useful transformation of indicator's value into a given range (e.g. 0-254 for producing a grayscale image) which means very low (or high for `grayscaleMaxValue`) values might be excluded on purpose.
* `grayscaleMaxValue` upper bound of indicator's value range. See above.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

formdata.description: Projection (SRID code) of the `geometry` parameter value
geoJSON providing the area to be classified

Optional name of the classification.

Classifications are uniquely identified by sequentialy generated dates (it's done that way so results can be accessed in exacly same way as any other indicator). This parameter allows to define a descriptive label for the classification.
Beginning of the classification time period
Ending of the classification time period
Minimum coverege of both train and target data for a given feature (`indicator x date`) to be used in the classification.

Maximum number of features used for the classification.

Bigger number generally increases classification accuracy but lower the number of features, the quicker classification is performed.

Features are selected using the mutual information criterion.
Number of trees used by the random forest classification algorithm.
Minimum probability to keep the predicted class in the output. Pixels with lower probability are assigned the `ambigous` class.
List of indicators (see the `/indicator` endpoint) used for the classifciation.

variable.description: (Required) Base classification identifier - see GET on the `/classification` endpoint

request.description:
Reruns a given classification overwriting its parameters with the ones provided by the request body.

Parameters not provided by the request body are taken from the previous classification run.

Parameters specified in the request body overwrite the base classification parameters.

query.description:
Id of an indicator to be used as the 1st (_red_) channel.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Id of an indicator to be used as the 2nd (_green_) channel.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Id of an indicator to be used as the 3rd (_blue_) channel.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Defines the queried area as a registered polygon with a given id.
  
If this parameter is used:
  
* `ownerId` must be provided as well.
* authorization is performed against the polygon's owner account (instead of API users accounts)

Id of the `polygonId` owner.
  
To be provided only when `polygonId` parameter is used.

Defines the queried area as a XYZ tile in the `x_y_z` format.
  
See [here](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames) for details.
  
Can be combined with `geometry` or `polygonId`. In such a case the returned raster extent will be determined by this parameter but all pixels outside of `geometry`/`polygonId` will be set to no data.

Defines the queried area as a geoJSON geometry.
  
Geometry's projection should be provided with the `srcSrid` parameter.

Defines the queried area as a bounding box in the `x1,y1,x2,y2` format.
  
Coordinates projection should be provided with the `srcSrid` parameter.
An EPSG code of request's spatial parameters (like `geometry`), e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator).

Raster data zoom level.
  
The raster piramids level to be used to fetch the data from - see [here](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames#Resolution_and_Scale) for details.
  
Range of available values vary between indicators. You can check it using the `/indicator` endpoint.

The default value is the maximum value available for a given indicator.

A buffer size (in meters) to be applied to the `geometry`.
  
Usefeul when `geometry` is a point or to assure returned raster data contains also pixels which centroids don't intersect th `geometry`.

When negative number is provided, the final `geometry` will be a bounding box of original `geometry` with a positive buffer value applied.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

A value of `now` indicates the current date.

A default value is the current date.
An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

Beginning of the queried time period.

The default value is `date - period`.

End of the queried time period.

The default value is `date + period`.

If not present or with the `0` value, data is gathered from actual acquistions.

If `daily=1`, interpolated daily data is used instead. This assures data exists for each day in the requested time period. Daily data are generated on the fly and cached. It means if you request data outside of cache, generating them will take (a lot of) time.

This parameter is still in experimental phase and may not work correctly.

Minimum coverage provided by an acquisition to be included in the response.
  
0 means no coverage and 1 means full coverage only.
  
Providing a value will cause coverage statistics to be included in the response.

Default value varies between indicators. You can check it using the `/indciator` endpoint.

Determines the way raster values are scaled.
  
* raw - use values as they are stored in the database (e.g. 0-80 for LAI)
* real - rescale values to indicator's phisical values range (e.g. 0-8 fro LAI)
* stdfloat - standardize to mean 0 and standard deviation 1 within the scene
* stdbyte - standardize to mean 127 and standard deviation 25 within the scene
* stretch - transform in a way the minimum value within the scene equals 0 and maximum equals 254
* grayscale - transform in a way minimum phisical value of the indicator corresponds to 0 and maximum to 254

Response format.
  
The actual content of the `application/*` responses depends on `encode` parameter value.

`image/tiff` response format returns acquisitions stacked as bands.

As `image/jpeg`, `image/png` and geoJSON response formats are unable to return more that one acquisition, only the most recent one is returned.

Returned raster data format.
  
It doesn't determine the response format (this is determined by the `format` parameter) and is affected by the `encode` parameter.

Determines the way raster data values are represented.

* `raw` means raster data will be provided as they are. This value is set automatically for `image/*` reponse formats (when `format` equals to `image/png`, `image/jpeg` or `image/tiff`) and is invalid for other response formats.
* `base64` and `hex` means raster data will be base64 or hex encoded. This settings are valid only when `format` equals to `application/json` and `rasterFormat` is one of `image/png`, `image/jpeg` or `image/tiff`.
* `values` causes pixes values to be converted into a vector representation. If the `format` indicates geoJSON response, every pixel will be turned into a geoJSON feature and for `application/json` response format pixels will be represented by a collection of objects providing pixel position and value. The way pixel position is represented is determined by the `position` parameter.
* `stats` causes raster data to be skipped and only summary statistics (valid pixel count, requested area coverage, min, max, mean value, standard deviation) to be returned.

The position within a pixel being used as a pixel's vector representation.

* `corner` indicates upper-left corner
* `center` indicates center
* `polygon` indicates a polygon covering whole pixel area
Maximum number of acqusitions returned (0 means no limit).

An EPSG code of returned spatial objects projection, e.g. 4326 (WGS-84) or 3857 (Web Mercator)

If not provided `srcSrid` parameter value is used and if `srcSrid` parameter isn't provided as well, a default value of `4326` is assumed.

request.description:
`/indicator/{indicatorId}/rasterData` endpoint equivalent for getting true and false color RGB composites.

For detailed description see the `/indicator/{indicatorId}/rasterData` endpoint. There are only a few noticable differences:

* indicators to be used as R/G/B channels are indicated using `r`, `g` and `b` query parameters (see below) instead of the `{indicatorId}` path parameter
* the `colorMap` parameter isn't supported
* as a single date image is already multiband, it's impossible to stack output of many dates into one `image/tiff`

It's worth noting that:

* Supplied parameters are applied to all bands.
* If an indicator is not stored on the `[0, 255]` scale (see the `grayscaleMinValue` and `grayscaleMaxValue` reported for a given indicator by the `/indicator` endpoint) it might be worth to set `scale` to `grayscale`.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic
Added as a part of security scheme: basic

query.description:
Indicator name.

The `/indicator` endpoint provides a list of all available indicators.

Indicators availbility may vary across both spatial and temporal domain.

An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

A value of `now` indicates the current date.

A default value is the current date.
An alternative way of defining the time period. If `dateFrom` or `dateTo` aren't provided, their default values is `date - period` and `date + period`, respectively.

Beginning of the queried time period.

The default value is `date - period`.

End of the queried time period.

The default value is `date + period`.

If not present or with the `0` value, data is gathered from actual acquistions.

If `daily=1`, interpolated daily data is used instead. This assures data exists for each day in the requested time period. Daily data are generated on the fly and cached. It means if you request data outside of cache, generating them will take (a lot of) time.

This parameter is still in experimental phase and may not work correctly.

request.description:
WMTS getCapabilities endpoint.

As number of layers provided by the whole database can be huge (up to few thousands), the endpoint takes optional parameters allowing to limit reported layers only to given indicator and/or time period.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

response.name: Access to a given indicator denied or no access rights to the whole endpoint.

header.description: Added as a part of security scheme: basic

A zip file containing a set of shapefile files or an eAMA XML file.
